awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Optimized Deployment of Antarctic Surface Weather Observations
awd_abstract_narration:
Numerical experiments are  to be used to test probabilistic predictions as to the optimal and sub-optimal siting of surface Automated Weather Station (AWS) observations in Antarctica. Sensor placement is a generic problem across the goesciences, and this project may have far-reaching impact as to fidelity and cost of observational networks. In particular, problems where measurements are difficult to obtain and/or expensive may be prioritized objectively with the approach tested here. If successful, this research provides the basis for an objectively optimized augmentation or re-configuration of the AWS network to meet climate monitoring (such as locating new or paleoclimate proxy records) and weather forecasting goals. 

Gridded data from (archived) Antarctic Mesoscale Prediction Systems (AMPS) will be used by University of Washington and NCAR researchers to optimize the spatial correlation length scales for the existing AWS network via ensemble sensitivity theory.  These predictions of optimal station placement will in turn be subject to observing systems experiments, using both data denial and reconfiguration approaches.
A related line of enquiry is to be an evaluation of the current locations of the active Antarctic radiosonde network, as judged by the network?s ability to account for tropospheric variance in archived AMPS forecast temperature data. Sonde measurements also may collocate with validation observations from infrared soundings from satellites, or GPS radio occultation.

por.por_cntn:
A generic problem in science and engineering concerns the placement of observing sensors: given certain constraints (e.g., a limited budget), an observing objective (what we wish to observe), and instruments with known error characteristics, what is the optimal distribution ("design") of the observing network? Here we developed a new approach to solving this problem with specific application to automatic weather stations (AWS) in Antarctica. Given the harsh conditions on the continent, it is expensive and time-consuming to maintain a weather observing network, so we wish to predict the configuration of an optimal network, and test those predictions against real field observations. For monitoring near-surface air temperature across the continent, our results show clearly that the Megadunes region of East Antarctica is the most important location for observations, and none are currently routinely taken there. Similar results are found for both observing and predicting near-surface air temperature. Although the results are sensitive to the size of the data sample used to perform the calculations, standard ensemble methods ("covariance localization") work effectively. Tests of the network-design predictions are performed on a network of real AWS observations, which show good agreement between the predicted and actual impact. Furthermore, comparing results for the optimal networks against randomly chosen networks shows that the optimal networks significantly outperform the random networks for all network sizes.
